latest news.eng_title: It's a Great Moment for Municipal Bonds. Investors Should Avoid the Election Noise.
latest news.summary: Despite the upcoming US election and market volatility, investors can benefit from opportunities in the bond market, particularly in municipal bonds. All-in yields are attractive across fixed income sectors, and real interest rates are near historical highs. The current environment, with a too-close-to-call election and trillions of investable assets parked in cash, presents a chance for municipal bonds to shine. The increase in supply from Covid-19 stimulus funds has softened muni markets, creating attractive buying opportunities in the new issue market. The forward pull in supply will likely lead to a slowdown as the year ends, which should create an imbalance in the other direction, pushing up prices. With the Treasury curve remaining inverted to flat, investors have $6.4 trillion parked in money market funds, but municipal bonds offer an attractive return, particularly on an after-tax basis. The muni curve is much steeper than the Treasury curve, and the muni-to-treasury ratio indicates a spread at its widest level since Fall 2023. As the Fed is expected to kick off an easing cycle, bond inflows are shifting from shorter- to longer-term maturities, and we expect this trend to accelerate. The fundamentals that support local governments are stronger today than ever, with state reserves and rainy-day funds at their highest levels in decades. Munis are a high-quality asset class, with a strong fundamental risk profile, and local governments are financially stronger today than they were before previous downturns.
latest news.title: It's a Great Moment for Municipal Bonds. Investors Should Avoid the Election Noise.

latest news.eng_title: Nasdaq Shows Pessimism On Rate Cut; Closes In Red, Dow Jones & S&P 500 Shutters With Marginal Gains
latest news.summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average set a record, rising 228 points or 0.6% to surpass its prior all-time high. The S&P 500 index ticked up by 0.1% to climb within 0.6% of its own record. However, the Nasdaq composite slipped 0.5% as big technology stocks gave back some of their gains. The Federal Reserve's upcoming meeting is expected to bring a rate cut, with a 63% probability of a half-percentage point reduction, up from 30% a week ago. This move is seen as a relief for the economy, which has been slowed down to contain high inflation. However, some critics argue that the Fed is moving too slowly, raising the possibility of a recession.
latest news.title: Nasdaq Shows Pessimism On Rate Cut; Closes In Red, Dow Jones & S&P 500 Shutters With Marginal Gains

latest news.eng_title: Cyclicals surge, Fed rates, seasonality: Market Takeaways
latest news.summary: Yahoo Finance senior reporter Jared Blikre discusses the day's top market movements, including the surge in cyclical sectors such as utilities (XLU) and the weight of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision later this week. Blikre notes that the Dow hit a record close, while Apple and the tech sector fell. He highlights the defensive nature of real estate and utilities, but also notes the potential for a surprise Fed rate cut, which could be a big surprise. Additionally, Blikre discusses the yield curve inversion and its potential implications for the economy. He also touches on September seasonality trends, which often see increased volatility and potential market unrest. However, he emphasizes that historical probabilities are just that, and anything can happen in the markets.
latest news.title: Cyclicals surge, Fed rates, seasonality: Market Takeaways

latest news.eng_title: Dow Hits New Record as Bond Yields Keep Falling
latest news.summary: The Dow closed at a record high of 228 points, or 0.6%, on Monday, with the S&P 500 up 0.1% and the Nasdaq Composite down 0.5%. Bond yields continued to fall, with the 2-year Treasury note yield at 3.554%, its lowest since Sept. 8, 2022, and the 10-year yield at 3.622%, its lowest since June 1, 2023. The shift in bond yields follows a change in the debate over the Federal Reserve's next move on interest rates, with odds of a half-point rate cut increasing to 63% from 50% on Friday. Former New York Federal Reserve President William Dudley believes the Fed will favor a half-point rate cut, saying, 'It's about to get a lot busier' as the Fed's September meeting approaches.
latest news.title: Dow Hits New Record as Bond Yields Keep Falling

latest news.eng_title: Dow Closes at All-Time High, Recoups September Losses
latest news.summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at an all-time high, recouping its losses from early September. The S&P 500 rose close to its own record, but was held back by losses in Big Tech companies like Apple and Nvidia. Alcoa jumped 6.5% after announcing it would sell its ownership stake in a Saudi Arabian joint venture. However, drops for influential Big Tech stocks kept indexes in check. Traders are betting that the Federal Reserve will cut its main interest rate by a larger-than-usual amount, with a 61% chance of a half-point cut, up from 50% on Friday and 30% a week ago. A Fed cut of half a percentage point would likely be the best case for the stock market in the short term, but the job market's performance over the next three to six months will be more important for stocks' direction.
latest news.title: Dow Closes at All-Time High, Recoups September Losses

latest news.eng_title: US two-year yield falls to lowest since September 2022
latest news.summary: The U.S. Treasury two-year yield fell to its lowest in two years on Monday, reaching 3.528%, while the 10-year yield slid for a second straight session. Investors are weighing the odds of a half-percentage point interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve this week. Former New York Federal Reserve President Bill Dudley said there was a strong case for a 50-basis-point cut, while investors made sizable bets on that outcome. The yield curve steepened for a third straight session, with the spread comparing 10-year and two-year yields widening to as much as 10 bps. Ian Lyngen, director of fixed income strategy at BMO Capital Markets, wrote, 'While we're still in the 25-bp camp, we'll concede that the more aggressively the market prices in 50 bp, the more compelled the Fed will be to follow-through with such a move.' However, some in the market were skeptical about a 50-basis-point cut, citing still-sticky inflation and uncertainty around the November U.S. presidential election. Jack McIntyre, portfolio manager for global fixed income at Brandywine Global Investment Management, said, 'I don't think 50 (basis points) is warranted, because 25 gives them more optionality to say, 'Hey, we can do more, but it's an election year.'
latest news.title: US two-year yield falls to lowest since September 2022

latest news.eng_title: Weekly Forecast, September 13, 2024: Treasury Yield Declines Continue
latest news.summary: The U.S. Treasury yield curve has been simulated 100,000 times to predict future interest rates. The results show a 20.2% probability of an inverted yield curve by September 1, 2034, and a 12.1% probability of negative 3-month Treasury bill rates by September 2, 2033. The most likely range for the 3-month U.S. Treasury bill yield in ten years is from 0% to 1%, and for the 10-year Treasury yield, it is from 2% to 3%. The simulation also shows that the probability of default for a 10-year Treasury bond purchased at par value of $100 with a 5% initial market value of equity to market value of asset ratio is 44.95%. The detailed probability distribution for both the 3-month Treasury bill rate and the 10-year U.S. Treasury yield 10 years forward is presented, showing the probability of where rates will be at each time step in 1 percent 'rate buckets'.
latest news.title: Weekly Forecast, September 13, 2024: Treasury Yield Declines Continue

latest news.eng_title: The Latest Inflation Reports Are in... Is the Wild Ride Over?
latest news.summary: The latest inflation reports, including the Consumer Price Index (CPI) and Producer Price Index (PPI), show that inflation is cooling down. The CPI rose 0.2% in August, while the PPI rose 0.2% as well. The core rate of CPI, which excludes food and energy, rose 0.3% in August and remained at 3.2% year-over-year. Despite this, owners' equivalent rent (OER) has been a sticking point, rising 0.5% in August and 5.2% year-over-year. The Federal Reserve is set to cut key interest rates at its policy meeting on September 18, and these economic reports suggest that inflation is within the central bank's target range. The 10-year Treasury yield has fallen to about 3.7%, and the yield curve is now officially un-inverted, easing fears of a recession. Louis Navellier warns that an upcoming 'financial tsunami' driven by AI will be more violent and severe than any financial crisis we've ever seen, and advises investing in world-class companies to survive this shift.
latest news.title: The Latest Inflation Reports Are in... Is the Wild Ride Over?

latest news.eng_title: How to know if the market is heading for a correction or a simple adjustment: the signals that managers watch for
latest news.summary: The market is heading for a correction or a simple adjustment, and managers are watching for certain signals. The downward path for rates has already begun, with the ECB cutting rates and the Fed expected to follow. However, the process of acclimatisation to lower rates is delicate, and the risk of recession looms. Analysts and managers refer to a handful of indicators to scrutinise the direction of the market, including unemployment in the US, which has fallen to 4.2%, but job creation was below expectations. Victor Alvargonzález, strategy director of Nexstep Finance, says, 'US unemployment will have a bearing on everything, and the confirmation of the market's soft landing scenario depends on it.' Volatility has been on edge, with the Vix index reaching over 60 points, and the debt curve has been inverted for the longest period ever seen. The yield curve is showing signs of a return to normality, and bond rates are falling sharply in expectation of rate cuts. However, the market may be pricing in too much optimism, with the Fed expected to cut rates by 225 basis points by the end of 2025. The technology sector has been affected by rising interest rates and is now not enjoying the prospect of cuts. Fears of a recession have focused sales on the stock market, particularly in the stocks that had risen the most, such as Nvidia. Managers do not doubt the potential of US technology, but there are concerns about the slowdown in China, which threatens to lead to a recession due to the crisis in its real estate sector.
latest news.title: How to know if the market is heading for a correction or a simple adjustment: the signals that managers watch for

news knowledge.eng_title: U.S. Private Domestic Sector Surplus Points To Better Markets In September
news knowledge.summary: The US private domestic sector recorded a surplus of $397 billion in August 2024, a positive result for asset markets. The fiscal injection from the federal government was unusually large for this time of year, which could be a strategic move to boost the economy before the election. The sectoral balance data suggests that the stock market (SPX) will stay in positive territory and finish the month higher than it began. The long-term outlook shows a boom until 2025, followed by a downturn due to a declining working-age population and reduced aggregate demand. The author believes that the Fed will not lower interest rates until there is a real crisis, and instead, rates will be raised to cool an overheating economy. The working-age population is peaking and causing aggregate demand to rise, but will decline after 2025, leading to a recession and low interest rates. The yield curve has inverted once and un-inverted for the second time, indicating a potential recession in the coming months.
news knowledge.title: U.S. Private Domestic Sector Surplus Points To Better Markets In September

news knowledge.eng_title: Why you shouldn't succumb to stock market pessimism
news knowledge.summary: The recent stock market downturn has led to a pessimistic view of the market, with many investors fearing a recession. However, this view is not supported by the data. The yield curve has 'un-inverted', which is a sign that a slowdown has actually arrived, but this is not necessarily a cause for concern. In fact, nearly three-quarters of shares are in an uptrend, and earnings forecasts for 2024 continue to look for near double-digit growth. As Morgan Housel says, 'Pessimism holds a special place in our hearts. It sounds smarter. It's intellectually captivating and it's paid more attention than optimism, which is often viewed as being oblivious to risk.' However, pessimism only rarely makes sense for investors, and the progression of stock markets over the long haul has been labelled 'the triumph of the optimists'. As Housel also said: 'If you want to do better as an investor, the single most powerful thing you can do is increase your time horizon.'
news knowledge.title: Why you shouldn't succumb to stock market pessimism

news knowledge.eng_title: The Yield Curve Righted Briefly This Week. What Does That Say About Recession Fears?
news knowledge.summary: The yield curve briefly inverted itself on Wednesday, but this was short-lived as it fell back into negative territory on Thursday. Historically, an inverted yield curve has indicated a recession is on the way, as investors expect higher yields for longer-term debt. However, some experts believe the brief righting of the yield curve is not a positive signal, as previous cycles have shown a re-steepening of the curve before a recession. Mike O'Rourke, chief market strategist for JonesTrading, attributed the move to optimism over the Federal Reserve's plan to cut its benchmark interest rate in September. Jim Reid, Deutsche Bank Strategist, cautioned that the historic precedent is not favorable, and we should be cautious in being too optimistic about the inversion. 'The bullish flattening of the yield curve might be considered a positive if the economy or markets had ever been held back by its inversion,' O'Rourke wrote. 'However, the historic precedent isn't particularly favourable on this front,' Reid wrote. 'So we have to be cautious in being too optimistic about waving bye to an inversion.'
news knowledge.title: The Yield Curve Righted Briefly This Week. What Does That Say About Recession Fears?

news knowledge.eng_title: US 2/10 Treasury yield curve turns positive
news knowledge.summary: The yield curve between two-year and 10-year Treasury note yields turned positive on Wednesday, which may be a bearish indicator for the U.S. economy. This part of the yield curve has been mostly inverted since July 2022, but the current inversion has lasted longer than in previous episodes. According to Karen Brettell, the curve typically turns positive before an economic downturn sets in as investors price in interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. The yield curve between two- and 10-year yields was last at 0.40 basis points.
news knowledge.title: US 2/10 Treasury yield curve turns positive

news knowledge.eng_title: Yield Curve Inversion Reversal: A Shift in Interest Rates
news knowledge.summary: According to Stephen Auth, Executive Vice President of Federated Hermes, we are experiencing a phase of dis-inversion of the yield curve, with interest rates returning to a more normal configuration. The cost of financing Treasuries is increasing, with the 2-year bond at 3.95% and the 10-year bond at 3.86%. In Europe, the 10-year Bund yield remains at 2.23%, following recent data that confirmed the weakness of the German economy. Germany's GDP has fallen by 0.1% in the second quarter, while it has stagnated on an annual basis. The decline in private consumption and the decline in the construction sector have contributed to this slowdown, exacerbated by a worsening consumer sentiment, with the confidence index falling to -22 points in September forecasts. The BTP-Bund spread is expanding to 134.6 basis points. Klaas Knot, the governor of the Dutch central bank, has indicated that the ECB may gradually reduce interest rates, provided that inflation converges to 2% by 2025. Knot has also emphasized the need for stricter fiscal discipline from governments to support the ECB's monetary policy.
news knowledge.title: Curva dei rendimenti in dis-inversione

news knowledge.eng_title: Morning Bid: Markets reassured by the Powell put
news knowledge.summary: Markets are reassured by Fed Chairman Powell's emphasis on the health of the labor market, which has lowered the bar for a 50 basis point interest rate cut in September. The yield curve is inverted, with 10-year yields at 3.79%, just 10 basis points under the 2-year yield. The Atlanta Fed GDPNow measure has slowed to an annualized 2.0%, and real consumer spending figures on Friday will help refine this number. Flash estimates for EU inflation are also due on Friday, and analysts expect a benign reading that will allow the ECB to cut interest rates as expected on September 19. Nvidia's earnings results on Wednesday will be a key event, with markets looking for $28.8 billion in sales and Q3 guidance around $32 billion. Options imply a 9% or more move in the stock after the results, given its market cap of almost $3.2 trillion.
news knowledge.title: Morning Bid: Markets reassured by the Powell put

news knowledge.eng_title: The Yield Curve's Inversion: A Reliable Indicator of an Impending Recession?
news knowledge.summary: The yield curve, a historically reliable indicator of an impending recession in the US, has been inverted since June 2022, following the Federal Reserve's tightening monetary policy and mixed expectations about the economy's prospects. However, the curve suddenly returned to its normal shape on September 4, with the 10-year Treasury yield surpassing the 2-year yield. This brief period of normalcy was short-lived, as the curve inverted again on Wednesday, with the spread between the two yields widening in favor of the longer-term bonds during the Thursday and Friday sessions. If the yield curve's inversion signals a recession, does its return to normality mean the threat has passed? The yield curve is a graphical representation of the relationship between the yields of bonds with different maturities, such as the difference between the yields of 2-year and 10-year Treasury bonds. Typically, the yield curve is upward-sloping, with shorter-term bonds yielding less than longer-term bonds. However, when the curve inverts, shorter-term bonds yield more than longer-term bonds, causing concern in the markets. A rising yield curve is often a sign of high inflation, as higher inflation expectations drive investors to demand higher yields for longer-term bonds to compensate for the expected erosion of purchasing power. The yield curve typically inverts when investors expect a recession, triggered by the Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates to combat inflation. The curve usually returns to its normal shape when the Fed begins to lower interest rates or when the market expects this to happen. Some economists believe that the yield curve's inversion often precedes a recession, while others argue that it is a reliable indicator of an impending downturn. The current yield curve has been inverted for a record 793 days, or approximately 26 months, without a recession occurring. Even if the yield curve returns to its normal shape and stabilizes for a long period, this does not necessarily mean that the economy will not experience a downturn. Historical data show that problems often begin when long periods of inversion end. The most recent four recessions (in 1990, 2001, 2007, and 2020) began after the yield curve returned to its normal shape, with the downturn starting 3-6 months later, according to 'Dow Jones Market Data.' In the coming months, it will become clear whether the Fed's interest rate hikes have pushed the economy into a recession or whether it has successfully controlled inflation without a downturn, according to 'Jim Reid,' head of global economics and thematic research at 'Deutsche Bank.' Time will also reveal whether the yield curve has lost its role as a leading indicator in this economic cycle or if it has simply sent out its warning signals earlier than in other cycles.
news knowledge.title: ركود وإخفاق الفيدرالي .. ماذا تعني عودة منحنى العائد إلى طبيعته بعد عامين من انقلابه؟

news knowledge.eng_title: Fed shouldn't react to one number, Chicago Fed's Goolsbee says (NASDAQ:TLT)
news knowledge.summary: Chicago Fed President Austan Goolsbee stated that the jobs data reported on Friday does not indicate a recession. However, he emphasized that the Federal Reserve would take action if they see conditions deteriorating. Goolsbee said, 'We're going to take all the measures, we shouldn't react to one number.' He also mentioned that the policymakers can wait for more data before the FOMC's September meeting, saying, 'We should always be forward-looking.' Goolsbee pointed out that the yield curve has been inverted for two years, but there's been no recession, and that the pandemic created a situation where historical correlations didn't hold. U.S. equities futures tumbled and bond prices climbed on recession fears in Monday trading.
news knowledge.title: Fed shouldn't react to one number, Chicago Fed's Goolsbee says (NASDAQ:TLT)

news knowledge.eng_title: Yen's Surge Continues, While PBOC Surprises With Another Rate Cut, And U.S. 2-30 Year Yield Curve Ends Inversion
news knowledge.summary: The capital markets are experiencing a surge in the yen, with the dollar falling 6.1% against the yen in three weeks. The PBOC has cut interest rates twice this week, and the US 2-30 year yield curve is no longer inverted. The dollar-bloc currencies and Scandis are bearing the brunt of the downside adjustment among the G10 currencies. Equities are in a sea of red, with the Nikkei falling 3.3% and most bourses off more than 1%. The US 2-10 year yield curve is the least inverted in two years, while the 2-30 year curve is positively sloped by the most in two years. Gold is extending its retreat, and September WTI is under pressure.
news knowledge.title: Yen's Surge Continues, While PBOC Surprises With Another Rate Cut, And U.S. 2-30 Year Yield Curve Ends Inversion
